docs.title: Hello Data Points 👋
docs.text:
Desorption

A small, fast CLI to display styled file/folder trees — perfect for documenting project structure, exporting to Markdown, or quickly inspecting repos.

docs.title: Install
docs.text:
From PyPIFrom UVFrom SourceWindows PowerShell 
# From PyPI
pip install show-file-tree

# From UV
uv pip install show-file-tree
From Source
# From source (dev)
git clone https://github.com/Rudra-G-23/show-file-tree.git

cd show-file-tree
python -m venv .venv
Windows PowerShell
.venv\Scripts\Activate.ps1
pip install -e ".[all]"

docs.text:

docs.title: Why use show-file-tree?
docs.text:
• Fast, memory-safe traversal — suitable for large directories.
  • Pretty terminal output — icons, counts, human-readable sizes.
  • Powerful filtering — globs, mtime/ctime windows.
  • Markdown export — create readable project documentation automatically.
  • Themes & ASCII fallback — works in CI or minimal terminals.
  • and many more .....

docs.title: --exclude / -e
docs.text: The --exclude flag allows you to skip specific files or directories when building the tree. You can use glob patterns (wildcards) to match multiple paths.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
# Exclude all log files
show-file-tree  --exclude "*.log"

# Exclude a specific folder
show-file-tree  --exclude "tests/*"

docs.title: Files in project
docs.text:
src/
tests/
README.md
debug.log
config.yaml

docs.title: Command
docs.text: show-file-tree  --exclude "*.log" --exclude "tests/*"

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
├── 📁 src
├── README.md
└── config.yaml

debug.log and tests/ are excluded from the tree.

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
• Multiple --exclude flags can be combined for fine-grained filtering.
  • Combine with --include to focus on specific file types while ignoring others:
show-file-tree  --include "*.py" --exclude "tests/*"
  • Works with --format md to generate filtered Markdown documentation.

docs.title: --include / -i
docs.text: The --include flag allows you to show only specific files or directories when building the tree. You can use glob patterns (wildcards) to match multiple paths.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
# Include only Python files
show-file-tree  --include "*.py"

# Include all Markdown files
show-file-tree  --include "*.md"

docs.title: Files in project
docs.text:
src/
tests/
README.md
debug.log
config.yaml

docs.title: Command
docs.text: show-file-tree . --include "*.py" --include "*.md"

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
├── 📁 src
│   └── main.py
└── README.md

Only *.py and *.md files are included in the tree.

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
• Multiple --include flags can be combined to include several file types.
  • Combine with --exclude to refine filtering:
show-file-tree  --include "*.py" --exclude "tests/*"
  • Works with --format md to generate filtered Markdown documentation.

docs.title: Creation Time Filters
docs.text:
show-file-tree supports filtering by file creation time using the following flags:

  • --ctime-after <YYYY-MM-DD> — Include only files created after the specified date.
  • --ctime-before <YYYY-MM-DD> — Include only files created before the specified date.

These filters are useful for auditing recent changes or generating snapshots of files created within a specific period.

docs.title: Include files created after a certain date
docs.text: show-file-tree  --ctime-after 2025-01-01

docs.title: Include files created before a certain date
docs.text: show-file-tree  --ctime-before 2025-06-01

docs.title: Combine both
docs.text:
show-file-tree  --ctime-after 2025-01-01 --ctime-before 2025-06-01

Only files created between Jan 1, 2025 and Jun 1, 2025 will appear.

docs.title: Files in project
docs.text:
file1.py   (created 2024-12-10)
file2.py   (created 2025-02-15)
file3.py   (created 2025-05-20)
file4.py   (created 2025-07-01)

docs.title: Command
docs.text: show-file-tree  --ctime-after 2025-01-01 --ctime-before 2025-06-01

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
├── file2.py
└── file3.py

Files outside the date range are excluded.

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
• Dates must be in YYYY-MM-DD format.
  • Combine with other flags like --max-depth or --sort for precise views:
show-file-tree  --ctime-after 2025-01-01 --max-depth 2 --sort name
  • Works with --format md to export time-filtered Markdown trees.

docs.title: Modification Time Filters
docs.text:
show-file-tree supports filtering by file modification time using the following flags:

  • --mtime-after <YYYY-MM-DD> — Include only files modified after the specified date.
  • --mtime-before <YYYY-MM-DD> — Include only files modified before the specified date.

These filters are useful for tracking recent changes or documenting updates within a specific timeframe.

docs.title: Include files modified after a certain date
docs.text: show-file-tree  --mtime-after 2025-01-01

docs.title: Include files modified before a certain date
docs.text: show-file-tree  --mtime-before 2025-06-01

docs.title: Combine both
docs.text:
show-file-tree  --mtime-after 2025-01-01 --mtime-before 2025-06-01

Only files modified between Jan 1, 2025 and Jun 1, 2025 will appear.

docs.title: Files in project
docs.text:
file1.py   (modified 2024-12-10)
file2.py   (modified 2025-02-15)
file3.py   (modified 2025-05-20)
file4.py   (modified 2025-07-01)

docs.title: Command
docs.text: show-file-tree  --mtime-after 2025-01-01 --mtime-before 2025-06-01

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
├── file2.py
└── file3.py

Files outside the date range are excluded.

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
• Dates must be in YYYY-MM-DD format.
  • Combine with other flags like --max-depth, --sort, or --count for more detailed views:
show-file-tree  --mtime-after 2025-01-01 --max-depth 2 --count
  • Works with --format md to export modification-time filtered Markdown trees.

docs.title: About
docs.text:
show-file-tree — A small, fast CLI tool to display styled file/folder trees with rich options (colors, icons, sizes, filtering, Markdown export).

Author: Rudra Prasad Bhuyan License : MIT

Quick facts

  • Purpose: Quickly visualize project structure in terminal and export readable Markdown documentation.
  • Primary use-cases: developer docs, repo inspection, CI-friendly tree outputs.

docs.title: Get this info from the CLI
docs.text:
About Command
show-file-tree --about

Example output:

Output of `--about` command
show-file-tree v0.0.1
A small, fast CLI tool to display styled file/folder trees with rich options.

Author: Rudra Prasad Bhuyan
License: MIT

docs.title: Useful links
docs.text:
• Repo: https://github.com/Rudra-G-23/show-file-tree
  • PyPI: https://pypi.org/project/show-file-tree/

docs.title: ✨ Key Features of show-file-tree
docs.text:
1. Styled Tree Visualization – Display folder and file structures in a clean, readable tree format.
  2. Color Themes & Icons – Choose from themes (colorful, monokai, light, nocolor) with or without icons.
  3. Depth Control – Limit recursion depth with -d / --max-depth for concise trees.
  4. Size & Count Display – Show file sizes and directory item counts.
  5. Sorting & Ordering – Sort output by name or size, in ascending or descending order.
  6. Filtering Support – Include/exclude files with glob patterns and time-based filters (mtime, ctime).
  7. Gitignore Awareness – Automatically respects .gitignore (or bypass with --no-gitignore).
  8. Markdown Export – Export the entire file tree to a .md file for documentation.
  9. Hidden Files Option – Easily toggle visibility of hidden files and directories.
  10. Top N Insights – Show top N largest or most recently modified files in the tree.

docs.title: Version
docs.text: The --version flag displays the current installed version of show-file-tree.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: show-file-tree --version

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
show-file-tree --version
show-file-tree version: v0.0.1

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
• Useful to verify your installation before running commands.
  • Helpful when reporting bugs or issues to confirm the version you are using.

docs.title: How to update
docs.text:
If you installed from PyPI, update with:

pip install --upgrade show-file-tree

docs.title: Reporting version-specific issues
docs.text:
When opening an issue, please include:

  • show-file-tree --version output (exact text)
  • OS and Python version (python --version)
  • A minimal reproduction (command used + small sample tree or repo link)

docs.title: Release notes / changelog
docs.text: See CHANGELOG.md for release history and detailed notes.

docs.title: --count
docs.text: The --count flag displays the number of files and directories inside each folder in the tree. This makes it easy to see folder contents at a glance without expanding everything.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: show-file-tree  --count

docs.title: Without --count
docs.text:
├── 📁 docs
│   └── readme.md
├── 📁 src
│   └── main.py
└── LICENSE

docs.title: With --count
docs.text:
├── 📁 docs (3f, 2d)
│   └── readme.md
├── 📁 src (5f, 1d)
└── LICENSE

Legend:

  • 3f = 3 files
  • 2d = 2 subdirectories

docs.title: Tip
docs.text:
Combine --count with other display flags:

show-file-tree  --count --size --theme monokai

This shows folder counts, file sizes, and a colored theme in one view.

docs.title: Why it’s useful
docs.text:
• Quickly assess folder contents without opening directories.
  • Helpful in documentation, code reviews, or project analysis.
  • Works well with --max-depth for summarized folder overviews.

docs.title: --format
docs.text:
The --format flag lets you choose how the tree is displayed or exported.

  • tree (default) — Display the tree in the terminal with optional icons, counts, and sizes.
  • md — Export the tree to a Markdown file for documentation purposes.

docs.title: Terminal tree (default)
docs.text: show-file-tree .

docs.title: Export to Markdown
docs.text:
show-file-tree --format md /path/to/project

This creates a file named <rootname>-file-tree.md in your current directory.

docs.title: Terminal output (--format tree)
docs.text:
├── 📁 docs
│   └── readme.md
├── 📁 src
│   └── main.py
└── LICENSE

docs.title: Markdown export (--format md)
docs.text:
# Project Tree

- docs/
  - readme.md
- src/
  - main.py
- LICENSE

docs.title: Tip
docs.text: Combine --format md with other flags like --size or --count to generate rich, documented project trees.

docs.title: --no-icons
docs.text: The --no-icons flag disables file/folder icons in the output. This is useful if: - You’re working in a terminal that doesn’t support Unicode emojis. - You prefer a plain ASCII output. - You want minimal, icon-free Markdown exports.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: show-file-tree  --no-icons

docs.title: Default (with icons)
docs.text:
├── 📁 docs
│   └── 📝 readme.md
├── 📁 src
│   └── 🐍 main.py
└── 📖 LICENSE

docs.title: With --no-icons
docs.text:
├── docs
│   └── readme.md
├── src
│   └── main.py
└── LICENSE

docs.title: Behind the scenes
docs.text:
By default, show-file-tree uses a rich icon mapping for file types:

File Type / Extension Icon Meaning / Notes Folders 📁 / 📂 Closed / Open folder Generic file 📄 Default file .py 🐍 Python script .js, .jsx 📜 JavaScript file .ts, .tsx 📜 TypeScript file .html 🌐 HTML file .css, .scss 🎨 Stylesheet .json 📦 JSON data .md 📝 Markdown file readme.md (exact match) 📖 README file .git, .gitignore 🌿 Git-related file .png, .jpg, .jpeg, etc. 🖼️ Image files .zip, .tar, .gz, etc. 📦 Archive/compressed file .mp3, .wav 🎵 Audio file .mp4, .mov, .avi 🎬 Video file .ttf, .otf, .woff, etc. 🔤 Font files .exe, .bin (generic bin) ⚙️ Binary file .yml, .yaml, .ini, etc. 🔧 Config file .lock 🔒 Lock file license 📜 License file

If any file type is missing then you can create an Github Issues

docs.title: Tip
docs.text: You can combine --no-icons with other options such as --size, --count, or --theme for a clean but informative tree.

docs.title: --size
docs.text: The --size flag shows the size of files and folders in the tree. Sizes are displayed in human-readable units (KB, MB, GB) for easy reference.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
# Show tree with sizes
show-file-tree  --size

docs.title: Without --size
docs.text:
├── 📁 docs
│   └── readme.md
├── 📁 src
│   └── main.py
└── LICENSE

docs.title: With --size
docs.text:
├── 📁 docs (12 KB)
│   └── readme.md (5 KB)
├── 📁 src (150 KB)
│   └── main.py (50 KB)
└── LICENSE (1 KB)

Legend:

  • Folder sizes are summed from the files inside.
  • Files show their individual size next to the name.

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
• Combine with --count to see both sizes and file counts:
show-file-tree  --size --count
  • Combine with --format md to export size-annotated Markdown trees.

docs.title: --theme
docs.text: The --theme flag controls the color theme for the tree output in the terminal. It affects folder/file colors and makes the output easier to read.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
# Apply a theme
show-file-tree  --theme monokai

docs.title: Available Themes
docs.text: Theme Description colorful Default. Bright, colorful icons and folders. monokai Dark theme inspired by Monokai editor colors. light Light theme suitable for light terminal backgrounds. nocolor Plain ASCII output without colors (useful for CI or minimal terminals).

docs.title: Default (colorful)
docs.text:
├── 📁 docs
│   └── 📝 readme.md
├── 📁 src
│   └── 🐍 main.py
└── 📖 LICENSE

docs.title: Monokai theme
docs.text: # Same tree, but colored for Monokai theme

docs.title: No color
docs.text:
├── docs
│   └── readme.md
├── src
│   └── main.py
└── LICENSE

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
• Combine --theme with --size or --count for a full-featured, colorful tree.
  • Use nocolor for plain outputs suitable for Markdown export or CI pipelines:
show-file-tree  --theme nocolor --size --count

docs.title: --order
docs.text:
The --order flag controls the sorting order of files and directories in the tree.

  • asc — Sort in ascending order (default).
  • desc — Sort in descending order.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
# Sort by name in descending order
show-file-tree  --sort name --order desc

# Sort by size in ascending order
show-file-tree  --sort size --order asc

docs.title: Ascending order (default)
docs.text:
├── README.md
├── docs
└── src

docs.title: Descending order
docs.text:
├── src
├── docs
└── README.md

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
• Always combine --order with --sort to define both sort criteria and direction.
  • Works with --format md, --size, or --count for customized tree outputs.

```

docs.title: --sort
docs.text: The --sort flag controls how files and directories are sorted before displaying the tree.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
show-file-tree  --sort name
show-file-tree  --sort size

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• name — Sort alphabetically (default).
  • size — Sort by file or folder size (smallest → largest).

docs.title: Sort by name (default)
docs.text:
show-file-tree .

Output (simplified):

├── 📁 docs
├── 📁 src
└── 📄 README.md

docs.title: Sort by size
docs.text:
show-file-tree . --sort size

Output (simplified):

└── 📄 README.md (25 KB)
├── 📁 src (100 KB)
└── 📁 docs (200 KB)

docs.title: Tip
docs.text: You can combine --sort with --order to control ascending/descending order.

docs.title: --gitignore / --no-gitignore
docs.text: The --gitignore flag makes show-file-tree respect .gitignore files, excluding ignored files and folders from the tree. The --no-gitignore flag ignores .gitignore, showing all files and folders.

docs.title: Respect .gitignore (default)
docs.text:
show-file-tree  --gitignore

Only files not listed in .gitignore appear.

docs.title: Ignore .gitignore
docs.text:
show-file-tree  --no-gitignore

All files are displayed, even if ignored in Git.

docs.title: .gitignore contents:
docs.text:
__pycache__/
*.log
.env

docs.title: With --gitignore
docs.text:
├── 📁 src
│   └── main.py
└── README.md

Ignored: __pycache__/, .env, .log files.

docs.title: With --no-gitignore
docs.text:
├── 📁 src
│   ├── main.py
│   └── __pycache__/main.cpython-310.pyc
├── .env
├── debug.log
└── README.md

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
• Useful in CI pipelines where you want a complete file tree.
  • Combine with --hidden to show hidden files that are also ignored by Git.
  • Combine with --format md for full documentation including ignored files:
show-file-tree  --no-gitignore --format md

docs.title: --hidden
docs.text: The --hidden flag displays hidden files and directories in your tree output. Hidden files typically start with a dot (.) on Unix-like systems (e.g., .git, .env) or are marked as hidden on Windows.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
# Include hidden files in the tree
show-file-tree  --hidden

docs.title: Without --hidden
docs.text:
├── 📁 src
│   └── main.py
└── README.md

docs.title: With --hidden
docs.text:
├── 📁 .git
├── 📁 src
│   └── main.py
├── .env
└── README.md

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
• Combine with --gitignore to respect .gitignore but still show hidden files not ignored by Git:
show-file-tree  --hidden --gitignore
  • Combine with --format md to generate Markdown documentation including hidden files.
  • Useful for project auditing, debugging, or full repo visualization.

docs.title: --max-depth / -d
docs.text: The --max-depth flag limits how deep the tree will traverse into directories. This is useful for large projects where you want a high-level overview without listing every nested file.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
# Show tree with a maximum depth of 2
show-file-tree  --max-depth 2

docs.title: Full tree (default)
docs.text:
├── 📁 src
│   ├── 📁 module1
│   │   ├── file1.py
│   │   └── file2.py
│   └── 📁 module2
│       └── file3.py
├── 📁 docs
│   └── readme.md
└── LICENSE

docs.title: With --max-depth 1
docs.text:
├── 📁 src
├── 📁 docs
└── LICENSE

docs.title: With --max-depth 2
docs.text:
├── 📁 src
│   ├── module1
│   └── module2
├── 📁 docs
└── LICENSE

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
• Combine with --count or --size for a summarized view of folders at each depth.
  • Combine with --format md to generate Markdown documentation for only the top levels of a project.
  • Useful for quick project overviews, documentation snapshots, or CI-friendly output.
